text: after months of feverish speculation
mayor bloomberg announced today that he
would seek a third term so should the
City Council vote to amend term limits I
plan to ask New Yorkers to look at my
record of independent leadership and
then decide if I've earned another term
the expectation is that the City Council
will likely pass the change in term
limits if the council passes it I will
sign it and I would plan to run for
re-election on the other hand there is
definitely a palpable sense of disquiet
and and and concern among a number of
City Council members well the issue is
not term limits and the issue is not how
great Mike Bloomberg has been or could
continue to be the issue is about
lawmaking
and the process itself there's a way to
use the charter revision Commission to
call a special election and have a
referendum and let the people decide
this issue that's the appropriate way to
go we have a process for referendums and
the people are spoken twice about this
the original votes on term limits were
controversial everything we do is
controversial that's what democracy is
all about he is someone who had a
reputation of being a fiscal manager and
he has dared the city through some tough
times but he is now sort of moving into
unknown territory as a politician who
claimed that he was not a politician he
is trying to get city voters who twice
before rejected the idea of changing
term limits to suddenly change it just
because of the economic crisis the
consequences of in New York City are
very real some of our largest employers
and most established companies are in
turmoil and others don't even exist
anymore the good news is that we have
planned for a slowdown in New York but
we may well be on the verge of a
meltdown and it's up to us to rise to
the occasion there are in fact a lot of
people on the New York Times blog
website who have said that that they
feel like it's a power grab some people
have described him as Putin esque or
Mugabe and others have said that he
indeed is the right person for the job
who's to say that he may not ask for a
four-term it's something that should be
asked and is all part of this new brave
new world that the mayor has opened up
for the residents of the city
